resources.string: \nMTBalance allows users to track their balance during rides in order to get feedback on their posture and technique, both for real-time and post-hoc evaluation. Information about sensor attachment, measuring, post-hoc feedback and application options can be found here.

insert gif of short overview of attachment here 


To start measuring balance performance, the user attaches multiple DOT IMU sensors to their bike in the following manner: 
 - Bike sensor: close to the center of mass of the bike. 
 - Position sensor: on the bike frame, facing the saddle. 
 - Crank sensor: to the left pedal crank, facing upwards. 


Two more sensors are attached to the ankle and knee on the left leg of the user. All sensors are to be orientated to the left side of the bike. Finally, the user chooses one of the 4 applicable feedback options and attaches said feedback if necessary. 


Note: for first time usage it is recommended to initialize the settings for the application as preferred. The settings are explained in more detail in the application options section.

gif of short overview of measuring process here 


The user can press the start ride button to begin a new ride. Once the sensors are connected and synchronized, the ride is started by pressing the play button. The sensors should be calibrated by having the bike and user stand in an upright position, followed by pressing the calibration button. During the ride the sensors can be re-calibrated at any time by pressing the button again. 


The sensors calculate the optimal balance zone and the current balance continuously. If the current balance deviates too much from the optimal balance, real-time feedback is applied depending on the feedback option chosen. The feedback attempts to steer the user back towards the optimal balance zone.

\nThe user is able to analyse the ride in more detail when a recording is finished. A card is generated in the rides tab of the application. This card gives a quick overview of the ride, including the following data:
- The ride time, in seconds and ride date.
- The feedback option used during the ride.
- The balance performance, as a percentage.
- The average balance threshold deviation, in cm.
- The average balance response time, in ms.

\nOnce a card is clicked, the user can investigate the ride in higher detail by the use of plots. The plots show the user balance during the ride with different filters. The following filters are available:
- Shows sideways balance fluctuation over time.
- Shows overt balance fluctuation over time.

The x-axis shows the sideways balance deviation, whereas the y-axis denotes the balance deviation in pitch. The green zones in the plots illustrate the optimal zone for the user balance to be in. As such, any point outside of these zones is a critical position at which the user would have received correctional feedback. 


Any point in the plot can be tapped to show precise information about its values, highlighting it in yellow. Points that share similar results are clustered together when tapped.

Participant number: the participant number of the user. The list of rides is filtered per participant, so only the rides of the current participant are visible. Selecting participant 0 enters test mode, allowing for trying out the application without saving ride data. 


Feedback method: the feedback method used during a ride.

Plot resolution: allows users to tweak the detail in the post-hoc feedback plots. Resolution is inversely proportional to the given value, with a resolution of 1 showing all collected data points. 


Threshold leniency: sets the threshold leniency during rides. A higher leniency allows for more mistakes while riding and vice versa. The chosen leniency is reflected in the green zones of plots.

Crank length: the length of the bike crank from the center to the pedal, in centimeters. Floating point precision is allowed. 


Lower leg length: the length of the user’s lower leg, from the ankle joint to the knee joint in centimeters. Floating point precision is allowed. 


Upper leg length: the length of the user’s upper leg, from the ankle joint to the hip joint in centimeters. Floating point precision is allowed.

Offset dimension: denotes the offset between the bike sensor and the center of the bike crank, in centimeters. Floating point precision is allowed. The following format is accepted: “x,y,z”. 


Hip dimension: denotes the offset between the hip joint and the center of mass of the user, in centimeters. Floating point precision is allowed. The following format is accepted: “x,y,z”.
